poem:
Title: In the Margins of Sahibs and Orwells

The sepia haze of Orwell's Burmese days,
Where Flory held the pen and Blair the gaze,
Moments transformed, dancing in bravado's fray,
Lost in ripples down the aged Irrawaddy's wave.
Suspicions whisper just beyond the page,
Who was the novice, who the sage?
In the murmur of ink, a tale is twirled,
Unending narrative, an altered world.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Burma Sahib by Paul Theroux review – George Orwell’s Burmese days vibrantly brought to life George Orwell’s first novel, Burmese Days, published in 1934, drew substantially on the five years he served in the Indian imperial police force at various stations along the Irrawaddy a decade earlier. You suspect, however, that his alter ego in that novel, John Flory, was a good deal more seasoned than the young writer, still called Eric Blair, had been". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
